list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The noise of the dogs barking bothered the old man.
Don’t bother to wrap it – I’ll take it as it is.
I had a lot of bother trying to deal with the people at the tax office.

list_definition.definition: something or someone that causes bother

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: What a bother all this is!

list_ex_of_english: When presenting his case, the author never bothers to give evidence.
Only a small number of researchers have bothered to ask the learners themselves what they think about these issues.
Not even his biographers have bothered to mention it.
They had too much 'rich loot ' to be bothered with trade.
The fact that an emperor bothered to discuss the problem of incorrect diagnosis and prescription of medications may hint at the scope of the problem.
Others moved regularly in and out from the neighboring counties, not even bothering to observe market days.
Since he also might not have, we should not be bothered by this result.
The money feels to him too much like a favor, bothering him more than the mortgage that doesn't put him under obligation to a sister-in-law.
